etymology.description: 毛(毛) (máo, "hairy") refers to the small hairs or fuzz found on the pods, and 豆(豆) (dòu, "bean") refers to the bean itself, which is inside the pod.
etymology.interpretation: The term 毛豆(毛豆) (máodòu) literally means "hairy bean," which describes the edamame, a young soy bean typically still in the pod. The pods are covered in fine hairs, which is why the descriptor 毛(毛) (máo, "hairy") is used. Edamame are popular as a snack or in dishes in East Asian cuisine.

examples.chinese: 我喜欢吃毛豆(我喜歡吃毛豆)。
天热时(天熱時)，一盘新鲜毛豆成为美味佳肴(一盤新鮮毛豆成為美味佳餚)。
examples.pinyin: Tiān rè shí, yī pán xīnxiān máodòu chéngwéi měiwèi jiāyáo.
examples.english: On hot days, a plate of fresh edamame becomes a delicious treat.

examples.chinese: 毛豆不仅美味(毛豆不僅美味)，而且富有营养(而且富有營養)。
examples.pinyin: Máodòu bù jǐn měiwèi, érqiě fùyǒu yíngyǎng.
examples.english: Edamame is not only delicious, but also nutritious.
